metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Head Clerk of Civil Surgeon's Office, Almora (Appellant)

facts.text: Appellant was Head Clerk of Civil Surgeon's office at Almora.
Police charge sheet dated November 13, 1949, alleged misappropriation by appellant of sum entrusted during his tenure as Head Clerk.
Charge under s. 409 IPC: between September 26, 1947, and February 11, 1948, appellant as public servant entrusted with Rs. 1,118-10-9 committed criminal breach of trust.
Trial court acquitted accused due to improper and unsatisfactory state of accounts in Civil Surgeon's office, for which accused and two successive Civil Surgeons were responsible.
High Court of Allahabad by judgment dated June 7, 1954, set aside acquittal, convicted under s. 409 IPC, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for three months.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on July 30, 1954 under Article 136 of Constitution.
Alleged misappropriation detected in March 1948 when Messrs May Baker Ltd. sent reminder for unpaid bills to Civil Surgeon, Almora.
Civil Surgeon Dr. Kar enquired; appellant was on leave; intimation sent, appellant replied by letter Exhibit P.8 on March 5, 1948, containing statements alleged to show guilt.
Money alleged misappropriated recovered from appellant and paid in March 1948 to firms whose bills were outstanding but shown as paid.
Matter handed to police in June 1949 on Deputy Commissioner Almora's order to Deputy Superintendent of Police.
Charge-sheet filed November 13, 1949; case submitted by S.P.O. Almora on July 10, 1950; received in court later.
Case registered in court of S.D.M. Almora on August 7, 1950 under s. 409 IPC.
Adjournments: November 7, 1950 - papers from Accountant-General needed; November 14, 1950 - nothing done; November 30, 1950 - Magistrate dismissed under s. 249 CrPC to record room.
District Government Counsel applied June 4, 1951 to summon witnesses for June 15, 1951.

Proceedings transferred to Judicial Officer, Almora; witnesses examined: P.W.1 Shib Lal Tewari June 16, 1951; P.W.2 Bishun Singh and P.W.3 Mohan Singh August 21, 1951; P.W.4 Shiv Lal Sah, P.W.5 D.N. Pandey October 25, 1951; P.W.6 Hira Lal November 10, 1951.
September 1, 1951: Application to examine Dr. D.M. Kar, Sri R.P. Kapoor, D.N. Pandey on commission.
Letter from Civil Surgeon Allahabad September 7, 1951 requiring Magistrate's certificate under s.507 CrPC and s.33 Evidence Act for medical officer.
Accountant-General letter September 14, 1951: R.P. Kapoor to attend September 19 but not authorised for unpublished records under s.123 Evidence Act.
Accused application October 16, 1951: case pending since March 1948, harassment, decide quickly.
Prosecution application October 26, 1951 for commission for three witnesses but noted presence necessary; Magistrate ordered commission.
Interrogatories submitted for various witnesses October 29, November 10, 14, 1951.
Accused objection November 12, 1951 to leading questions for Dr. Kar; Magistrate ordered modification.
Prosecution application November 14, 1951 for four more witnesses in person; Magistrate allowed only R.P. Kapoor once, others on commission.
Key witnesses (two Civil Surgeons, auditors) examined on commission by interrogatories.
Defence: undisbursed amounts kept in safe, disbursed later; cash books showed earlier entries but actual later; no dominion over money.
High Court rejected defence, relied on Ex. P.8 admissions for temporary misappropriation.
Trying Magistrate issued commissions himself on November 19, 1951 without application to District Magistrate as per s.503(2) CrPC; District Magistrate Almora only forwarded.

legal_issues.text: Whether the trial was vitiated by examining important prosecution witnesses (Civil Surgeons and auditor) on commission through interrogatories instead of in open court, without following proper procedure under s.503 CrPC.
Whether there was sufficient justification under s.503 CrPC for issuing commission due to delay, expense or inconvenience.
Whether the trying Magistrate properly approached the District Magistrate under s.503(2) CrPC for issuing commission.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defence that undisbursed amounts were kept in safe and disbursed later, no criminal misappropriation as no dominion over money.
Harassment due to protracted proceedings since 1948; request for quick decision.
Objection to leading questions in interrogatories; necessity for personal appearance and cross-examination in court.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant's letter Ex. P.8 showed guilt of criminal misappropriation.
Applications for commission due to case pending long time; presence of key witnesses necessary but sought commission.

court_reasoning.text: Cardinal principle of criminal jurisprudence: evidence against accused must be recorded in presence and open court for challenge, demeanour observation, effective cross-examination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Departure from open court only in exceptional cases under CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: s.503 CrPC allows commission only if attendance cannot be procured without unreasonable delay, expense, inconvenience; subordinate Magistrate must apply to District Magistrate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No such unreasonable factors shown for Civil Surgeons and auditor in UP.

court_reasoning.text: Trying Magistrate issued commission himself without applying to District Magistrate; District Magistrate only forwarded, no judicial order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-compliance with s.503(2) CrPC vitiates proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Important witnesses foundational to case must be examined in court; commission/interrogatories sparingly for formal witnesses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence on commission improper, excluded; fair trial denied.

holdings.text: Examination of essential witnesses on commission by interrogatories without proper procedure under CrPC vitiates trial; such evidence cannot be used against accused.
No justification for commission absent unreasonable delay/expense/inconvenience; attempt to summon in court required first.
District Magistrate must exercise judicial discretion on application; forwarding insufficient.

precedents_cited.relevance: Not proper to take evidence of important prosecution witness on commission merely inconvenient.
ss.503 and 506 CrPC to be used sparingly and only in clearest cases.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of criminal breach of trust by public servant charged.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Dismissal of case; procedure for commission of witnesses; interrogatories.

statutes_cited.name: Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for medical witness; privilege for unpublished official records.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held that the trial was vitiated due to improper issuance of commissions for examining key prosecution witnesses without following s.503 CrPC procedure, denying fair trial; evidence taken on commission excluded, proceedings invalid.

key_quotes.text: It is an established cardinal principle of Criminal jurisprudence... that in criminal proceedings the evidence against the accused should be recorded in his presence and in open court...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle violated leading to vitiation of trial.

key_quotes.text: The important witnesses on whose testimony the case against the accused person has to be established, must be examined in court...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule restricting commissions to non-essential witnesses.

key_quotes.text: This is a defect which goes to the root of the matter and is vital in content. Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final conclusion on invalidity of evidence and trial.
